Posts.Content: My experience..had psa test at 6 weeks and scored a 8.1 post surgery! So yesterday took another blood test and am awaiting results. Doc was surprised because pre op, like 6 mos ago, was 6.1. One explanation is it could have spiked and is still dropping..or some problem with the test results. At any rate we'll see latest score and go from there. Was not aware of the 90 day "finish line"! THANK YOU HIGHLANDER! Wife and I were not pleased having more hoops to jump thru

Posts.Content: Doing well, five hour procedure on Jan 20. Six incisions inc navel, nerves spared one side. Encapsulated. Dr says he does NOT use Rocco stitch...he reconstructs the urinary sphincter. But did have some physical issues not related to surgery!! First, wife and I had coughs and colds week before surgery...was worried about breathing, coughing etc messing up the procedure. Was advised its np as long as no fever. Well, after surgery imagine having to cough and blow your nose all the time?? Then, several hours after surgery, had reaction to anesthetic causing nausea and dry heaves...unbelievable, more agony!!! This was after fasting for 2 days!! My stomach was so painful and raw that I have just got my appetite back (4 days). I also suffer from GERD (acid reflux), so they gave me pepsid to help that and the effects of the antibiotic horse pills. Slowly getting back to normal. I set milestones to track progress..like first bowel movement, being able to tie my shoes..lol Here are couple hints that helped me, don't think I have heard them before: Charmin extra strong TP, good for the bow around the cath tube..stops drips and useful to dry cath connections and cleanups. Infections..use Bactine spray or lots of soap and water around buttocks genital-anal area (last time in hosp I came home with a staff infection!) Wash hands often, use clean towels!! Neosporin for tip of penis. Get a small tube with fine applicator point..so you don't have to use fingers (Dr recommended to me). Keep it lubed..lol Slippers and suspenders may help too. Plan how to use your comp laying down or standing up. Sitting was VERY painful for me. Don't be afraid to cut a hole in pants leg or pocket to route the cath tube. Tell them if you suspect problems w anesthesia and colds! Next milestones are Tues 28 for cath removal and pathology report, Dr was optimistic. Then we'll see the rest of the story. Rgds, Mike

After catheter removal, you'll be able to drive and you' ll start to feel like your old self. Good luck in joining our Zero Club and stay positive! Fran Fran, thanks! Posts.Content: Just wanted to say thanks to all you for taking the time to respond! This time of year is hectic, and worse for me trying to plan for the surgery... I was cruising along in very good health, not even on any meds..so am hopeful that's a plus in a easier recovery etc. It's still weird that my little bud will never act the same, but on a positive note my prognosis and attitude is very good and life will go on. Two more things..I asked the doc about me shaving the area, I am kinda hairy. He said NO, adds risk of infection? I meant like a week before.. And how long to drive? My wife needs me to get her around, shop, etc Thanks again, Mike BTW, in anticipation of being laid up, I bought a new laptop with Windows 8...now that's a way to add more stress. Or maybe a diversion???
Posts.Title: New Member with Questions and some observations

Posts.Content: Many thanks for the responses..I keep telling myself to be grateful for modern medicine too!! I see the possibility of the bladder being repositioned downward to "take up the slack" lol. My doc gave very little info on anything except on the fact that I WILL leak every time I sneeze or cough. He focused on survival rates, etc. Was also surprised to hear the reference to female anatomy...(man w/o prostate=female urinary tract) Yes I know this is a lengthy recovery...and scary, but am retired. I kinda have to take care of my wife (she does not drive) and she has been very troubled about my situation! BTW she was successfully treated for Non Hodgkins lymphoma...this is an easily treated cancer, luckily. Husband + wife both cancer patients? Weird Thanks again, Mike

Posts.Content: I went to Cleveland Clinic in Weston FL, just diagnosed (10/2013). Gleason 8 x2 and one Gleason 6, diagnosed early, nothing else affected. Doing the DaVinci on Jan 20. This was second opinion, gland is 60g, and was advised (x2) RP is best for my physical condition and age (64). My dad died 20 yrs ago from this cancer, very healthy all his life, but did not get aggressive treatments back then..crappy HMO...miserable death Cleveland Clinic also has ED specialists that offer ALL latest techniques...FYI My questions...this penis shortening thing was never mentioned..any new thoughts here? The Dr did mention that when he attaches the output of the bladder...your urinary tract becomes akin to female because the prostate is no longer there..holding the bladder up. I get the idea that pulling the organs close together pulls up the penis...and am afraid that my big 60g prostate will have more effect there... Also the dry orgasm..I get that, but is the vas clamped or re-routed? I think my info said that urine might be milky after orgasm! Thanks Guys...Mike

Posts.Content: Hey Vern, great to hear you are doing so well!! FYI we had same surgery, same day and my condition mimics yours, except I am retired and have time to rest as much as I want. Having less leakage each day, and at this point feel 100%, but am not pushing it. My incisions lost the superglue bout a week ago, and are almost invisible now! About the only lingering thing is "my boys" are somewhat red (itches, burns) and a little tender....but no diaper rash..lol Rgds, Mike

Posts.Content: Vern, my doc said to walk as much as possible, as did all the others on this forum. It's necessary to get the blood flowing for healing, bowles to "wake up" and get rid of gases they pumped you up with. The second day I managed to drag myself around the house for like 30 min, took my nap and felt noticeably better... Ran into a guy that I have hot seen in a while...turns out he had Davinci a while ago and we both used SAME doc...he also had EXCELLENT results, only problem he has is when he's out beer drinking...LOL. Funny comparing notes!!! I am not tender at all except for my belly button pinches once in a while...Glad you are getting back to 100%

Posts.Title: Different Results from Different Labs

Posts.Content: You are not alone in having a high PSA after surgery...assuming you had a radical. If you look at my signature, that is my history. What they should have explained is that they HOPE it goes undetectable, meaning that all the suspect tissues were removed. If any microscopic cells remain these will add up and be read as a PSA number (not undetectable). I am waiting for my next PSA test in Aug at which time doc will decide if Lupron and Casodex is working. They also look at the half life time it takes for PSA to decrease, and determine new treatments, and how long to stay on Lupron. Please add your history (go to settings where you input your signature), it helps for more advice! Rgds, Mike

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon Mikem350, what if any side affects did you have on Lupton, Casodex? B Not too bad at all, worst is hot flashes. Posts.Title: psa 5.1 after 6 months on lupron

Posts.Content: You are not alone in having a high PSA after surgery...assuming you had a radical. If you look at my signature, that is my history. What they should have explained is that they HOPE it goes undetectable, meaning that all the suspect tissues were removed. If any microscopic cells remain these will add up and be read as a PSA number (not undetectable). I am waiting for my next PSA test in Aug at which time doc will decide if Lupron and Casodex is working. They also look at the half life time it takes for PSA to decrease, and determine new treatments, and how long to stay on Lupron. Please add your history (go to settings where you input your signature), it helps for more advice! Rgds, Mike

Posts.Title: psa 5.1 after 6 months on lupron

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mikla Well it has been 2 weeks and thought I would give an update: Dr. Tewari and his staff are top notch. Even the PA who was text-ing me constantly on Sunday when I had the problem peeing. He said he was extremely confident that he got it all. The way he does it is by doing a MRI prior to surgery and then using that as a map to make his first cuts and removal of the prostate. After he removes it he takes several samples and gets an immediate pathology (while this is going on, he went out and talked to my wife). Based on this pathology, he decides if he needs to take more, which he did not need to do for me. All and all, extremely pleased with the results to date. Your doc seems very careful and methodical, exactly the way you would want! I had a cough and cold going in too, then was vomiting in recovery from anesthetic...worse than the operation itself, which was "uneventful". From what I have been reading here you are way ahead of the curve. I am 11 days post op, and am just beginning to get urine control..have to remember to keep squeezing my butt hole to prevent leaks, bit sitting or sleeping 100% dry. ED very pronounced, and was told to use a vac pump asap. My G8's required one side nerve removal, precautionary 3 lymph nodes too..so as they say your results will vary...did you have complete nerve sparing?

Posts.Content: Well I am in the hot flash group, under hormone therapy. I have lost count of how many per day and nite...LOTS From Wiki: The autonomic nervous system (ANS or visceral nervous system or involuntary nervous system) is the part of the peripheral nervous system that acts as a control system that functions largely below the level of consciousness to control visceral functions,[1] including heart rate, digestion, respiratory rate, salivation, perspiration, pupillary dilation, micturition (urination), sexual arousal, breathing and swallowing. Most autonomous functions are involuntary but they can often work in conjunction with the somatic nervous system which provides voluntary control. Very Interesting as to the case for hypnosis. Will bring this up at my next Dr visit next month...lol!

Posts.Title: Help With Medicare Medigap Cancer Drug Coverage

Posts.Content: The RO has been reviewing my case, and wont start any rad until he completely understands my condition. This was a real surprise to me because I was fully expecting to be told to hurry up and get the treatments going!!! This is ok to me because my wife needs about 20 more treatments herself, and being her caregiver I need to take her anyway. The issue is why my PSA rose steeply after the RP surgery, even with clean path report. Couple mos later I was put on hormones. The RO wants to see exactly where he needs to irradiate which makes sense to me. I have read many times of others getting the "prostate bed" treated after RP but never quite understood that. He is reviewing my path reports, CT scans, PSA history etc. So far no further scans have been mentioned. Being on hormones definitely complicates things! So, still waiting to hear from the RO.....right now he says take my upcoming Lupron shot

Posts.Title: Salvage Radiation Questions, and should I see a Urologist or Oncologist after surgery

Posts.Content: Have been on HT with good success, manageable side effects, PSA is undetectable for approx. 15 mos now. Was rising post surgery. Check my signature. But, when taking my wife to her Radiation Oncologist (her visit as a Lymphoma patient) I discussed my case and he strongly advised me to have radiation. I have read Dr Walsh and this forum (THANKS for ALL THE HELP!) and know the limits of HT and probably will move ahead with salvage RT. So, what is a typical treatment schedule for salvage rad, preparations, and potential bad things happening? My wife took a sodium fluoride PET/CT for bone cancer (neg results)...at a special center, is this for PC? Also, does a urologist normally treat PC or should I use an Oncologist? I asked wife's oncologist and he was very agreeable to have me as a patient. My urologist did the biopsy and gives me the Lupron shots. I do not have the ability to travel to a specialized center as I am primary caregiver for my wife, but there are many local doctors. Thanks, Mike

Posts.Content: "We conclude that prostatic ductal adenocarcinoma seen on needle biopsy implies more advanced cancer with a shortened time to progression" Acinar prostate cancer is less aggressive, most common type Ductal is very aggressive by comparison My ductal and acinar cancer were diagnosed after my prostate was biopsied after being removed. My G8 was confirmed ductal, a more aggressive and much less common cancer. Post op my PSA continued to rise, even with a clean pathology report, forcing me into hormone treatments. The thinking is it progressed to distant lymph nodes. Guess I will re-read the above to understand more..lol Wolf..nice avatar, 30yr ex Motorolan here, thanks for the info!

Posts.Title: Which comes first rise in psa or pain at site of spread ?

Posts.Content: "We conclude that prostatic ductal adenocarcinoma seen on needle biopsy implies more advanced cancer with a shortened time to progression" Acinar prostate cancer is less aggressive, most common type Ductal is very aggressive by comparison My ductal and acinar cancer were diagnosed after my prostate was biopsied after being removed. My G8 was confirmed ductal, a more aggressive and much less common cancer. Post op my PSA continued to rise, even with a clean pathology report, forcing me into hormone treatments. The thinking is it progressed to distant lymph nodes. Guess I will re-read the above to understand more..lol Wolf..nice avatar, 30yr ex Motorolan here, thanks for the info!

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer options

Posts.Content: Here are my reactions about 2 months after a shot of Lupron and Casodex. The shot is every 3 mos and daily Casodex. so far not so bad. Some hot flashes, mainly at night, causing lots of tossing and turning. Some loss of energy, maybe some memory loss and headaches. Zero sex interest....worst is trying to stay asleep at night. The effects come on gradually, and many say keep getting worse...Am not into exercising at all, but do stay active. Wife and I she has non Hodgkins lymphoma) take lots of naps. The shot was given in my upper butt, no big deal either. I guess the phrase "your results may vary" applies to HT. I just hope it works as promised, my PSA has been RISING into double digits after surgery. Next PSA test will determine further more aggressive treatments. Maybe my luck will change.

Posts.Title: Prescribed Radiation Therapy after Surgery

Posts.Content: I saw my surgeon yesterday and received the horrible news that post RP my PSA is continuing to rise, doubling time of about 6 mos. If you check my signature the numbers are listed. He said that radiation is effective when the cancer areas are clearly defined which makes sense...and in my case recommended hormones (Casodex and 3 month injection to start). Am scheduled for a bone scan next week, but he does not feel that this will show anything anyway. A younger doc in training said bone scans usually only show problem areas when PSA = 25 or so. They feel some microscopic cells escaped to other body sites and lowering my testosterone levels via hormones is the proper treatment. I was HOPING for radiation as I do NOT want the low T side effects...guess you are lucky in your diagnosis. Maybe you can elaborate a little on your Dr recommendation for radiation, your age, and your Gleason score... Wow, realized that I totally hijacked your post...sorry but your story is so close to mine...and I just got more confused...any feedback appreciated! Mike

Posts.Title: Prescribed Radiation Therapy after Surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon I assume that radiation is not the 1st choice because the cancer currently is to small to target accurately. The last thing you want is a series of Luke Skywalker laser blasts going into your body on a hit and miss bases. You could always ask your doctor for the pros and cons of both. Brave Thank You the more info the better. That's what I think I heard from the doc that its too small or spread to who knows where, so no zapping. Was wondering why the OP was directed to radiation right away instead. My PSA is much higher and climbing. Mike
